text: An in vitro globin gene switching model based on differentiated embryonic stem cells .
We used mouse embryonic stem ( ES ) cells to study globin gene expression and switching in vitro .

We show that ES - derived embryoid bodies express the full complement of mouse embryonic globin genes in the correct temporal order and that on further differentiation , a switch occurs to the fetal / adult genes .
In addition , the erythroid - specific transcription factor <extra_id_0> NF-E1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> was shown to be expressed coordinately with that of globin in embryoid bodies .
We conclude from these experiments that the ES cell system provides a good model to study hematopoietic development .

When the human epsilon - or beta-globin genes driven by the dominant control region ( DCR ) are introduced into this system , the human <extra_id_0> epsilon-globin <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> gene , in contrast to the <extra_id_0> beta-globin <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> gene , is not deregulated by the presence of the DCR and is expressed strictly as an embryonic gene .
